Black Holes Don’t Suck (No, Really!)

The Cosmic Companion
Apr 2

Black holes have fascinated fans of space and science for a century, and ideas about the nature of these enigmatic objects have changed over the decades. These objects were first predicted, in detail, by Albert Einstein in his General Theory of Relativity in 1916, but ideas of black holes go back even further than his ground-breaking discovery.

In short, the escape velocity of any celestial body — the velocity at which an object needs to travel to escape the gravity of a planet, star, or other body, is dependent on the mass of the body and its diameter. When a star or other object shrinks (while keeping the same amount of mass), the escape velocity from its surface increases. If this escape velocity reaches the speed of light (which no object with rest mass can reach), then no object can escape from the body. Once the escape velocity exceeds the speed of light (denoted as c), then not even light can break free of the gravitational grip of the object, and a black hole is born.

The Four Flavors of Black Holes

At the center of a black hole lies the singularity, where the mass of the object is centered, and where the curvature of spacetime is at a maximum.

Black holes are surrounded by an event horizon, an area where the escape velocity from the object is exactly equal to the speed of light. If you come any closer than this boundary, it is impossible to escape (assuming you are larger than a subatomic particle — more on that later). It is within this event horizon that a black hole is truly black as seen from outside.

Today, we classify black holes into four varieties — stellar, supermassive, intermediate, and primordial.

Stellar Black Holes — The most familiar of these are stellar black holes, created when massive stars (at least three times larger than the Sun) collapse as they die, and no force of nature is able to halt their collapse. After a series of fits and starts, the star collapses into its final form as a black hole. There are, likely, a few hundred million of these black holes in the Milky Way Galaxy.

Supermassive Black Holes — These are typically found at the centers of nearly all galaxies. Supermassive black holes can have masses millions or billions of times greater than our own Sun. No one is certain how they form, although they could be the result of the merger of numerous stars or smaller black holes, which then feed off gas and dust in surrounding space.

Intermediate-Mass Black Holes (IMBH) — This is the newest type of black hole known to physicists, and the least-understood. They may form from a chain reaction of globular clusters falling together into an increasingly-massive object.

“Astronomers have been looking very hard for these medium-sized black holes. There have been hints that they exist, but the IMBHs have been acting like a long-lost relative that isn’t interested in being found,” said Tim Roberts of the University of Durham.

Primordial Black Holes — Following the Big Bang, rapidly expanding space may have coalesced in a manner which created tiny black holes, less massive than the Sun.

A Timeline of Understanding Black Holes

Late 18th Century — A pair of natural philosophers, John Michell and Pierre-Simon Laplace, used Newton’s laws of gravity to predict that gravity on some bodies could be so great that light could not escape, and they could not be seen from any significant distance. Michell referred to these bodies as “dark stars.”

1801 — The wave nature of light came into favor, leading physicists to believe that light would not be affected by gravity. This put a damper on the study of black holes which lasted 115 years.

1916 — Albert Einstein publishes his General Theory of Relativity, postulating warped spacetime for the first time. His findings contained evidence that bodies massive enough, or dense enough, could warp space to such a degree that light could never escape their surfaces. Within a year, physicist Karl Schwarzschild found how Einstein’s new equations would affect light within a gravitational field. He also found, for the first time, that crossing the event horizon of a black hole was a one-way ticket for any traveler foolhardy enough to cross its border.

1933 — This is when things got really complicated. Due to the bizarre nature of relativistic spacetime, events experienced by one observer are not the same as the same events witnessed by another observer at a different point in space time. George Lemaître found, for the first time, that if one person (whom he called Alice) crossed the event horizon of a black hole, she would not notice any special event to mark the occasion (apart from tidal forces and radiation, covered later in the article). However, an outside observer (Bob) would see Alice approach the black hole at an increasingly-slower rate, until he would see her stop just outside the event horizon. Bob would never view Alice crossing the boundary, while Alice would see herself cross the border (assuming she survived the journey).

September 1, 1939 — On the same day that Adolf Hitler invaded Poland, triggering the Second World War, physicists J Robert Oppenheimer and Hartland Snyder published On Continued Gravitational Contraction, in which they worked out the mathematics of a star contracting under its own gravity, forming a black hole. This paper is currently regarded as one of the most important works ever produced in the study of these bodies.

1971 — The first black hole, denoted Cygnus X-1, is detected by rockets equipped with Geiger counters. Three years later, famed physicist Stephen Hawking bet fellow researcher Kip Thorne that this object was not a black hole. In 1990, Hawking conceded the wager.

1973 — The name “black hole” first enters general use following the publication of a journal article, The Four Laws of Black Hole Mechanics, by James Bardeen, Brandon Carter, and Stephen Hawking.

2015 — The detection of gravitational waves by astronomers using the LIGO observatory formed the first direct evidence of black holes. The waves were found coming from a pair of binary black holes orbiting each other, warping space during their dance around each other.

2019 — A photo, created by a network of radio telescopes called the Event Horizon Telescope, is released for the first time showing the region around a black hole. Even prior to its release, this image was being hailed as one of the most important pictures ever taken in astronomy.

It is impossible to ever photograph a black hole itself (unless you are inside the event horizon, in which case you won’t be able to send the photograph to anyone else). However, the region around a black hole, including the spiral of matter spinning into it (called the accretion disk, often seen in science-fiction movies), is now being imaged for the first time by astronomers.

“As the attracted matter accelerates and heats up, it emits x-rays that radiate into space. Recent discoveries offer some tantalizing evidence that black holes have a dramatic influence on the neighborhoods around them — emitting powerful gamma ray bursts, devouring nearby stars, and spurring the growth of new stars in some areas while stalling it in others,” NASA officials explain on Share the Science.

The Ins and Outs of Black Holes

Any person or spacecraft approaching a black hole would be stretched out from tidal forces, as the force of gravity on the end of their craft nearest the black hole would be significantly greater than on the rear end. This would result in stretching of the spacecraft and any unfortunate passengers in a process known to astronomers and physicists as “spaghettification.”

Until recently, it was believed that these tidal forces would kill anyone foolhardy enough to approach a black hole. However, in 2012, researchers determined that the event horizon of a black hole forms a wall of radiation so powerful that it would easily kill any life form who ventured to close to the body long before they would be pulled to pieces by tidal forces.

Oddly, there is one way for a sub-atomic particles to escape the torrential grip of black holes. Quantum mechanics states that every particle in the Universe is accompanied by a matching anti-particle. If these pairs are created right at the event horizon of a black hole, one half can fall toward the singularity, while its partner breaks free. This process, known as Hawking radiation, can result in the evaporation of black holes over an extraordinarily long period of time.

The gravity of black holes simply holds on to objects unfortunate enough to encounter them. Unlike a vacuum, they do not pull objects toward them through the power of suction. Therefore, no matter what anyone says, black holes don’t suck.
